FacilityName: Ocean Beauty Seafoods inc. - Kodiak Division

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXCUTIVE SUMMARY

Ocean Beauty Seafoods
Kodiak, Alaska

Ocean Beauty Seafoods is a seafood processing plant situated on the harbor of the City of Kodiak, Kodak Island, Alaska.  The plant was initially constructed in the early nineteen hundreds and, as is true with most industrial plants, has undergone extensive modifications and additions over the years.  This plant is subject to the EPA Risk Management Program Rule as it has an ammonia refrigeration system which contains more then 10,000 pounds of ammonia.  Ocan Beauty Seafoods has complied with both the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard and he EPA Risk Management Program.

The City of Kodiak is located on the northeast coast of Kodiak Island and plant is locatd in the industrial/commercial area of the City, southeast of the city center.  Topographically, there is a steep mountain ridge close to and north and west of the plant.  Under th worst case release scenario, the ammonia cloud reaches only to the end of the marina where it dissipates to below 200ppm before reaching the city center.  The only human receptors in this are other seafood processing plants and commercial businesses that support the fishing industry.  As these other seafood processing plants are also subject to the Risk Management Program, they are prepared with emergency plans in the event of a relese.

The more sensitive types of receptor such as schools and hospitals would be unaffected for two reasons. First the public schools and the hospital in Kodiak are locted beyond the furthest point of the worst case distance that the ammonia cloud would travel.  Secondly, both the schools and the hospital are several hundred feet of elevation gain above sea level where the release would have occurred. Since ammonia clouds follow the lowest path, it is unlikely that any ammonia would reach these locations 

With a significiet release (>500 pounds), the affected receptors are in industrial andcommercial establishments near the plant.  These business

es would be contacted by phone so that they could activate their emergency plans.

The Kodiak area, like most of Alaska, is rich in wildlife, eagles, deer and other wildlife may wander near the plant site, although this happens infrequently.  It is possible, but unlikely, that an animal may be caught in a cloud.  Since this is an unlikely event and there are strong populations of animals on the island, this remote possibility should not be viewed with alarm.

The Ocean Beauty Kodiak plant is committed to a strong safety and accident prevention program.  Even before the RMP rule applied, Ocean Beauty participated in emergency respoinse training and drills.  There is a continuing dialogue with the Kodiak Fire Department who would be the first responder in the event of a significient release.
